wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 2/9/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top articles from around the industry so that you can stay up-to-date on the state of employee engagement in CSR and sustainability on the go.

What the Future of Gamification in the Workplace Looks Like

The author argues that until recently, the concept of gamified workplaces was vaguely defined and not taken seriously. He believes that over the course of the year, technology will prove that gamification is less about hype and more about productivity. Four predictions of what gamification in the workplace will look like in 2015 include 1) Employee focus, 2) The Holistic Corporation, 3) Self-serve Solutions, and 4) Integrated Analytics.

Why corporations ‘go green’ ahead of regulation, public policy.

Andersen Corp. has announced plans to achieve a reduction of solid waste, energy and water usage by 20% by 2020. This MPR News recorded interview provides details about Andersen Corp’s involvement with the CERES Climate Declaration and provides best practices. Andersen Corp’s VP of Sustainability, Jim Weglewski, believes it all starts with improving internal processes. With plans to practice lean manufacturing, focusing on internal quality issues, and recapturing waste and reintroducing it as raw material, Andersen continues to demonstrate sustainability leadership.

Why Engagement Happens in Employees’ Hearts, Not Their Minds

Mark Crowley, a leadership consultant, reflects on his experience to answer the question, What are the real drivers of human engagement in the workplace? His answer, although rather taboo at first, is love. He defends it with research from some of the top psychology professionals in the country and explains, The love I’m speaking of relates to the experience of positive emotions’the foundation of human motivation. Research suggests people need frequent exposure to these positive emotions every day, therefore workplaces must provide positive situations in order to have an impact on feelings of engagement, loyalty and love of work. His advice to leaders? Love your people.

Five Trends Driving Workplace Diversity in 2015

Diversity is predicted to be one of the top priorities for corporate responsibility agendas this year, and corporate diversity programs have never been so visible. This is encouraging since last year Deloitte reported that Diversity/Inclusion was one of the least important issues on leaders’ minds compared to other HR issues. The author, a diversity consultant, believes the added focus in 2015 is because more CEOs are piping up, semantics aren’t so subtle anymore, and diversity’s definition has changed.

Climate Change’s Bottom Line

A detailed account of the Risky Business Project, an unusual network of business and policy leaders determined to prepare American companies’particularly agricultural companies’for climate change. The group has commissioned studies to inform business leaders on climate change because they believe it could be potentially devastating to the business world if not properly dealt with. Their focus is to educate, encourage leaders and companies to embrace adaptation, and gradually prepare agribusiness for change.
